Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer erred in determining that a reasonably viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) existed for the applicant
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide evidence disproving the IFA; new evidence considered but found insufficient
Decision_Outcome: PRRA officer concluded that a viable IFA existed and that the ex-partner would not find the applicant after 8 years
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate lack of viable IFA and risk upon return
Credibility_Factor: Officer assessed that the applicant's fear was not substantiated given the passage of time (8 years)
Legal_Rule: Protection under IRPA if risk to life or danger of torture and no available IFA
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged errors in assessing state protection and IFA
Outcome_on_Merits: PRRA application denied due to existence of viable IFA
Key_Evidence_Considered: New evidence submitted post-refusal, duration since separation (8 years), location feasibility of IFA
Applicant_Challenge: Denial of second PRRA application based on IFA and state protection assessment
Defendant_Response: PRRA officer maintained decision based on reasonableness and sufficiency of analysis
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal claims, temporal factors
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of PRRA refusal and granting of protection
Outcome: PRRA refusal upheld; no protection granted
Remedy_Sought: Successful PRRA application and protected person status
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative decision subject to judicial review
Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court
Governing_Rule: Section 96 and 97 of IRPA regarding risk to life or torture without available IFA
